solution_line_template: He spent {workout_years}*{climbing_multiplier}=<<{workout_years}*{climbing_multiplier}={learning_to_climb_years}>>{learning_to_climb_years} years learning to climb
He spends {months_per_mountain}*{num_mountains}=<<{months_per_mountain}*{num_mountains}={total_climbing_months}>>{total_climbing_months} months climbing all {num_mountains} mountains

After a {diving_learning_months} month break, he starts diving so that is {total_climbing_months}+{diving_learning_months}=<<{total_climbing_months}+{diving_learning_months}={total_months_before_diving_completion}>>{total_months_before_diving_completion} months

So in total it all took {workout_years}+{learning_to_climb_years}+{total_years_from_climbing_and_diving_learning}+{diving_completion_years}=<<{workout_years}+{learning_to_climb_years}+{total_years_from_climbing_and_diving_learning}+{diving_completion_years}={total_time_taken}>>{total_time_taken} years
